ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This class was a combination of synchronous lecturing and also discussion/seminar with other students as with any other language course.
Virtual lectures and virtual discussions

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to make videos, improve my spelling, and have fun.

I significantly improved my writing ability by virtue of taking this class. I also expanded my vocabulary, and although I have forgotten a decent amount, just the familiarity with the words has improved my speaking and Korean cognitive skills. My speaking got marginally better, I believe, and I cleaned up a lot of bad Korean tendencies.
Writing Hangul.
How to write in Korean with proper grammar, different verb modes, grammatical structures

I actually improved a lot in my writing skills than I had expected. It really helped that I had already heard a lot of the grammar structures and vocab from home as a heritage student, and now I am much more aware of how I speak as well because I use the things that we have learned when I speak. It really is one of those classes that it may seem like there's not much happening in the moment, it really builds up overtime. Choi ssn was also very understanding and helped us a lot and checked on us to see if the material was too difficult or was going too fast. I thought the class was going a little fast, but I do understand that it had to if we wanted to get done on time, but it wasn't too overwhelming. I do think after taking the course, I have grown a lot in my writing, but of course, you should take other classes beyond this if you want to continue to improve. I did appreciate that this class did help in learning useful phrases and going through situations that students will likely encounter later in their life. like interviews and learning different honorifics.
Increased vocabulary of Korean words, grammar and writing skills, as well as dictation, reading comprehension and speaking
You learn formal korean grammar and writing skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The strengths: There is no class on Wednesday
The weaknesses: I think 132 is pretty misleading because it's a lot harder than people might expect it to be.

Strengths: Choi ssn is a nice person, really. She is a bit aloof when it comes to tech or modern day stuff but that makes for some funny moments in class. Maybe it was Zoom but wow there were so many "this is so meta humor lmao" moments in class.
Weaknesses: lessons could be a bit more engaging, more practice with reading could be done (feel like this was most lacking among all my skills), and additional writing tips.
Very good at practicing writing especially.

The course had students from different skill backgrounds, yet the material was gone through pretty quickly. Prof. Choi went through the exams really quickly, which was especially difficult given that the exams were in real-time (she would scroll through a document on her screen).

Strengths include learning lots of grammar and vocab that a student might encounter later in their career, speaking practice with a TA every week, homework assignments that reinforce what you learned in class, very flexible deadlines, easy access to the professor for help
Weaknesses: some people might have found the class to be too fast-paced, tests were done in very short time frames and I felt that I was rushing every time (I think making the tests shorter would help with the time crunch), you don't get too much practice in class but mostly outside of class, and it was kind of hard to connect to other students as the regular classroom setting is lost, but the breakout rooms were a good way to meet other students in the class.

Strength: Fast grading and ability to meet with professor

Weakness: Disorganized, and poor usage of zoom
Strengths: interesting class, always material to learn, instructor is flexible with some due dates Weaknesses: somewhat disorganized, difficult to track some assignments

Strengths: You get to practice writing a lot in class and through the assignments. The course is generally well organized and follows the book very closely, so you know what is expected of you.

Weaknesses: The vibes are off.

Strengths of this class are that it works of off a foundational knowledge and understanding of Korean, which is great for people who speak at home or are strongest with speaking/listening vs. reading/writing. However, I don't think the class translated well to an online format, and I found that it was often unclear what class expectations were, and when work was due as the syllabus and weekly assignments sheets did not often match up. I think that this course might benefit from being streamlined, or with more explanation during class time.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course materials on the canvas website were poorly organized, with vague titles which made it hard to find certain files and resources. Since the course was remote, the disorganization made it harder to grasp the content matter. Additionally, for the exams, the professor would scroll through a document she was sharing to the class. She would try to micromanage the time for every section, which made it really stressful to complete the exams. On top of that, sometimes, it was hard to understand what she was trying to communicate to the class.

The breakout rooms for student speaking and grammar practice was really nice. I definitely think that this should stay an important part of the course as it did help with speaking and getting to know the other students. This was my first language course at Yale, and I think it was pretty good given the covid situation: we had the lectures, and discussions and cultural readings that were translated pretty well over zoom. I don't have many criticisms towards the course.
The class mostly succeeded; possibly room for improvement in breakout room activities that are more clear on what the assignment/goals are
This was a required language course but only offered in one section, so the time difference for those not on campus was terrible.

I think that this course could be improved with more focus on how test taking is really different online. Where we might be getting an in person paper for a test, online it is much harder to test take when you are only offered part of the test for a specifically timed portion, while still having to look back and forth from your laptop to your paper. It felt as if the test timing was not adjusted with digital format in mind, and it made it hard to focus on the actually content of the test.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this class to other students if they have prior familiarity with Korean. Otherwise, I highly recommend starting from the beginning track. It's pretty difficult if you're barely familiar with the language.

Yes, if they do not have much experience with writing in Korean. This class cleaned up SO MANY gramatical errors of mine, and while my writing and speaking can still be a bit simpler at times, I no longer make any atrocious errors. I find that I write significantly better than my Korean friends who have not taken formal classes (despite being native speakers).
Yes!

If you want to learn Korean grammatical structures and become a better writer, you should take this course. However, if you want to hone your speaking and reading skills, I would recommend a different class. This course was mainly focused on grammar.

I would definitely recommend this course to a student who is fairly familiar with the language or has a decent basic foundation in Korean but really wants to improve their writing skills. I will say that the speaking proficiency among the students in the class varied, we were all had a weakness in writing, so I would not be too concerned if your speaking wasn't the best. The class is a good mix of discussion, lecture, breakout rooms, and homework assignments. I enjoyed the class and would definitely encourage L2 learners to continue on in the sequence or for a student to take the placement exam and get into the sequence.
Fun course, and reasonably easy for native speakers with some previous interaction with the language. Take this course if you want to improve your korean, especially in grammar/writing
